Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating a Nonparametric Method to Predict Longevity of Engineering Monitoring Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
As systems in engineering continue to become larger and more complex in nature, real time condition monitoring of such systems continues to be an important area of study in order to more accurately predict system failure and develop systems to prevent catastrophic consequences. Using probability and statistics tools, this research will develop a robust method to predict long term conditions of the systems being analyzed and to do so under conditions of unknown prior distributions. The research will be conducted under the mentorship of Professor Ming-Yen Cheng of National Taiwan University.

In the Bayesian approach, prior distributions are assumed, and posterior distributions are then established from assumptions of the prior and the model. Hence, we can find the probability via the appropriate threshold failure time and access the long-term condition of the system. When the prior is unknown, however, it is then important to be able to estimate the prior from samples generated by the signal time. The focus of this research proposal is to fit the unknown prior distribution with a smooth empirical distribution function based on kernel function and sequence of bandwidths to estimate the unknown prior distribution. The research will be conducted under the mentorship of Professor Ming-Yen Cheng, a noted statistician of National Taiwan University Department of Mathematics.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was to construct a density estimator from contaminated data in place of a Baysian prior method typically used in remaining useful life problems in reliability theory. The main problem is to estimate the residual life distribution uisng observed degradation data. Our approach was to construct a deconvolution kernel density estimator. Deconvolution is the process of estimating a density when the observations are contanimated by additive measurement errors. Typical work in decovolution problems assume the additive measurement errors are idependent and identiticaly distributed and follow a known distribution. Our main work in this project was the constuction of an estimator where the observations are contaminated data which also has a specfic dependent structure. In statistics, there are many methods to show an estimator is a "good" estimator. To prove the constructed deconvolution kernel density estimator is a good estimator, we found an upper bound of the mean integrated squared error of the constructed estimator which convergense to zero. Hence, showing the mean integrated squared error of our estimator also converges to zero. In this process, we were able to find optimal rates of convergence for this estimator. This result will allow us to estimate the residual life distrubution and calculate the remaining useful life of components in reliability theory.
